summary: US benchmark equity indexes declined on Friday as President Donald Trump's tariff threats against the U.S. President Trump threatened to impose more tariffs on the Chinese economy .

President Donald Trump dug in on his threat to impose a 50% tariff on the European Union . Trump said a potential 25% charge on smartphones would apply to all foreign-made devices . The president downplayed the ability of the EU to avoid a higher tariff rate, which he said would hit June 1 .  The S&P 500 dropped 0.7%, down for a fourth straight day . Apple led a selloff in tech, falling more than 3% . Trump said he was “not looking for a deal” with Brussels .  Trump dismissed concerns that his moves could result in higher prices for Americans . He said foreign countries and companies could absorb the cost of the tariffs . Still, he acknowledged that some costs could be passed on to consumers . The defiant tone came despite top administration officials saying earlier Friday that Trump was trying to drive US trading partners to strike better deals .  US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent expressed hope “this would light a fire under the EU. EU” The pivot was a notable change in tone from a G.7 finance ministers’ meeting earlier this week . Separately, Trump posted to social media that he already told Apple the company’s popular smartphones should be made in the US .  The EU’s trade chief, Maros Sefcovic, held a call with his US counterpart, Jamieson Greer, on Friday to take stock of negotiations . The commission “remains ready to work in good faith,” the commission said in a social media post . Irish Prime Minister Micheal Martin called Trump's suggestion “enormously disappointing”  New EU framework covers tariff and non-tariff barriers, ways to enhance economic security, mutual investments, strategic purchases and cooperation on global challenges . Aim of the paper was sent to the White House earlier this week, was to jump-start formal trade negotiations .  The EU is aiming to cooperate with the US, and is seeking a balanced and mutually beneficial deal . EU officials and many member states remain skeptical that the Trump administration is driven by similar goals . The EU plans to move forward with preparing countermeasures if negotiations fail to produce a satisfactory outcome .  “We are maintaining the same line: de-escalation, but we are ready to respond,” French trade minister Laurent Saint-Martin posted Friday . Trump lowered his so-called reciprocal rate on most EU exports to 10% from 20% for same amount of time .

President Donald Trump said the tariffs he threatened against Apple Inc. earlier Friday would also be aimed at a wider range of device makers . Trump indicated that the import levies would be “appropriately done” and ready for implementation by the end of June .  Trump’s demand for US-based manufacturing pose a stark challenge to Apple and Samsung, whose supply chains for their devices have been concentrated in Asia for years . Trump also threatened a 50% tariff on the European Union that would go into effect June 1, which weighed on the broader market .  Trump’s warning on Friday took shape after Apple signaled earlier this month that new tariffs would bring as much as $900 million in higher costs in the current quarter . Apple had already planned to transfer the bulk of its US-bound iPhone production to facilities in India .  Apple said earlier this year that it plans to spend $500 billion in the US over the next four years . Moving manufacturing of its signature iPhone and other devices to the US would be an enormous and expensive undertaking for Cupertino, California-based Apple .  The change threatens to cut Apple’s gross margin by 3 to 3.5 percentage points in fiscal 2026 . But moving iPhone production to the US would likely still be far more costly than paying the tariff . US equity indexes fell this week as the White House's budget bill triggered jitters in the Treasury . US equity markets fell as a result of jitters over White House budget bill .

Dollar Spot Index fell as much as 0.8% on Friday, extending a more-than-7% decline since the beginning of the year . The dollar is down for a fourth day in five after Trump’s latest threats of tariffs . Hedge funds, asset managers and other speculative traders continued to bet against the dollar .  The Canadian loonie strengthened to as much as 1.3709 per US currency, its strongest level since October . Seven currencies out of the group rose 1% or more against the greenback during Friday’s trading, with New Zealand and Australian dollars leading advances .  Speculative traders trimmed their positioning to $12.4 billion in the week ending May 20 from $16.5 billion in a week prior . Some of the angst has come as the Senate considers the tax bill, which includes a debt ceiling increase .  Investors are more wary of US assets and that is continuing to weigh on the dollar, a Rabobank strategist says . “Whether it be budget, inflation or growth concerns, investors are wary of U.S. assets,” she says .
US benchmark equity indexes closed lower on Friday, as President Donald Trump threatens new tariffs . President Trump has threatened to impose new tariffs on U.S. markets .

Stock markets dipped slightly Friday after Trump threatened a 50% tax on imports from the European Union as well as a 25% surcharge on products from Apple . The S&P 500 notched a daily decrease of 0.7% and a weekly drop of 1.7%. The Nasdaq had a daily decline of 1%, and the Dow Jones fell 0.6%.  On April 2, the 47th president unveiled a base 10% tax on imports from the U.S.’s trading partners, as well as more severe tariffs on dozens of countries, especially China . The stock and bond markets shuddered in response, and Trump walked back his tariff plans soon after . Last week, the markets rallied and posted a weekly gain .  Moody’s rating of U.S. credit has also weighed on markets . The credit ratings agency dropped its ranking of American debt from AAA to a rating of one rung below at Aa1 .
US benchmark equity indexes ended lower Friday as President Donald Trump threatened new tariffs . President Trump also threatened to impose new tariffs on Chinese and U.S. companies .
Tech stocks were in the red late Friday afternoon, with the Technology Select Sector SPDR Fund (XLK) in red . Tech stocks in red late on Friday afternoon .

Apple shares fell as much as 3% on Friday after President Trump said the company must pay at least a 25% tariff, unless iPhones sold in the US are manufactured domestically . Trump suggested the tariff policy would apply to Apple competitors like Samsung .  Apple expects to face a $900 million headwind as a result of tariffs in the current quarter . The company isworking to diversify its supply chain with heavy investments in India . Wall Street has warned that making devices in the US would result in much more expensive phones .  Wedbush analyst Dan Ives said it would take 5-10 years to shift production to the US . "We believe the concept of Apple producing iPhones in the US is a fairy tale that is not feasible," he added .

US benchmark equity indexes are on track to close lower on Friday after latest tariff threats by the US . The latest tariff threat by the White House comes after the latest round of threats by President Donald Trump .

Donald Trump has threatened to impose 50 per cent tariffs on the EU from next month . The president said negotiations with the bloc were “going nowhere” and warned he would impose the levy on all EU imports from June 1 . Mr Trump suggested the EU can only avoid tariffs “if they build plants here”  US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the president was frustrated at the EU's pace . Mr Trump also berated the EU as “very difficult to deal with’s ‘monetary manipulations’ and ‘ridiculous corporate penalties’  Threat of tit-for-tat tariffs sparked a sell-off for stock markets around the world . Brussels has already signed off on a more immediate €21bn package of levies of up to 50pc on products including wheat, motorcycles and clothing .  Wall Street’s ‘fear gauge’, the Vix, spiked to a more than two-week high, jumping as much as 25.9pc . The UK fared much better, with the FTSE 100 down just 0.2pc and the tech-heavy Nasdaq dropped by 1.6pc .  President’s rekindling of trade tensions comes almost exactly halfway through a 90-day “pause” in the tariffs that he set for almost every country on April 2 . The UK is one of the only countries to have so far negotiated a deal to fend off the resumption of tariffs .  Washington is said to be demanding unilateral tariff cuts from Brussels . Washington also wants Brussels to weaken rules governing American companies . Deal would see tariffs on industrial goods slashed to zero alongside reduction in levies on some agricultural products .  Mr Trump said any iPhone not made in the US would face a 25pc tariff . He said this would also apply to Samsung and other smartphone companies . Apple has shifted some iPhone production from China to India, but this would not be enough to avoid tariff .  Smartphones are currently exempted from Mr Trump’s most punishing tariffs on China . Shigeru Ishiba said he wanted to increase “investment, not tariffs” The two leaders held talks just after Ryosei Akazawa headed to Washington for a third round of talks .  Restricting sale of extreme ultraviolet (EUV) lithography equipment to China is the “single most important export control” the United States has in the area of chip manufacturing, the White House’s AI and crypto czar David Sacks has said . Dutch company ASML makes EUV chip-making machines, which produce the most sophisticated semiconductors .  Scott Bessent said that the US is not the cause of rising bond yields . Comments come after an auction for 20-year US bonds was hit by weak demand and yields on 30-year bonds hit 19-month highs .  Scott Bessent hopes his relationship with the German government will push Brussels to negotiate a better trade deal . He said he is 'very impressed' with his German counterpart, Lars Klingbeil . Mark Francois, the Tory chairman of the European Research Group, said the Trump tariffs showed why Britain was better off ‘well out’ of the EU .  Donald Trump has proposed a 50pc tariff on European Union goods starting June 1 . Mr Trump has always been sceptical about the EU as an organisation and his imposition of major tariffs highlights yet another reason why we’re well out of it, a senior official said .  Mr Trump has long resented the EU, repeatedly claiming it was formed to “screw” the US . He is now training his guns on Brussels after reaching a truce in his battle with Beijing .  Scott Bessent has said that he expects in-person negotiations to begin with China again . The US Treasury secretary said that several large trade deals could be made in the next two weeks .  The Irish premier has criticised Donald Trump’s latest threat to hike tariffs on EU goods . Micheál Martin said the current process of negotiations were ‘the best and only sustainable way forward”  FTSE 100 lost 0.2pc, Germany's main index fell 1.5pc and France's top index lost 1.7pc . Comments came after Donald Trump lashed out on the EU’s negotiating strategy, claiming: “Our discussions with them are going nowhere!”  The main losers will be the EU economies most exposed via goods exports to the US, notably Germany and Ireland . The UK will be hit less hard by an escalating US-EU trade war than if we had not left .  Diplomats reveal draft offer includes plans to boost purchases in strategic sectors . There would also be a concerted effort to work more closely on strategic industries, like steel, aluminium, semiconductors and electric vehicles . Brussels has suggested it could review its paperwork demands on US products, especially agricultural .  Euro Stoxx volatility index spiked to its highest in more than four weeks . Dollar index has fallen more than 0.6pc today and is on track for worst week since 'liberation day' Donald Trump agreed a trade deal with the UK earlier this month .  Donald Trump has said he is recommending a 50pc tariff on goods from the EU starting from June 1 . Volvo Cars boss Hakan Samuelsson has said that Volvo's American customers would have to pay more to cover tariff hikes . Mr Samuelsson told Reuters that a tariff would limit the ability of Volvo to sell its Belgium-made EX30 electric vehicle in the US .  French trade minister Laurent Saint-Martin has said Donald Trump’s threat of new tariffs against the EU are not helping trade negotiations . He said the EU is ‘ready to respond’ to the US President's threats . The car's starting price is now at $46,195 and shares in Volvo are down 4.5pc .  If fully implemented, 50pc US tariffs on European products would shave off some 0.6pp of GDP growth . It would also bring the eurozone economy close to recession danger .  S&P 500 currently down 1pc, Dow Jones down by 0.9pc and Nasdaq down by 1.2pc . Wall Street’s ‘fear gauge’, the Vix is up 13.5pc today .  US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent has hit out at the ‘quality’ of the EU’s proposals . Claimed that European countries are being left in the dark by Brussels negotiators . US and EU need to redouble efforts to renew their trade relationship .  British and European bond yields have fallen sharply following Donald Trump’s tariff announcement . The yield on 10-year gilts fell to around 4.7pc, while French and German yields fell to 3.25pc and 2.56pc .  The benchmark S&P 500 dropped 0.9pc, while the Dow Jones lost 0.8pc . The tech-heavy Nasdaq fell 1.1pc and Apple lost 2.3pc . Mr Trump has dialled back or paused many of his tariff threats in recent weeks .  The tech giant has a deeply ingrained supply chain in Asia, and that is going to be very difficult for it to extricate itself from . Apple hoped it could get around the worst of the tariffs by shipping iPhone products to the US from India and Vietnam . The US administration has not looked kindly on such tactics and is now threatening new tariffs .  Threats by Mr Trump to impose a 50pc tariff on EU nations could cause German GDP to be about 1.7pc smaller than it otherwise could have been . Ireland faces a comparative 4pc hit if pharmaceuticals are included, Capital Economics said .  EU member states have signed off on a €21bn (£17.6bn) package of retaliatory tariffs . List of US goods include wheat, motorcycles in a nod to the iconic Harley Davidson and clothing . A much larger list worth €95bn (£80bn) is waiting in the wings as the European Commission wrangle over possible targets .  Markets are reacting quickly and anxiously to Donald Trump’s latest social media post . But by saying only that he is “recommending” this 50pc tariff on the EU, has the president left himself some wriggle room? It has been widely reported in recent days that Washington is frustrated with the EU's offer on trade .  Oil prices have dropped following Donald Trump’s threats to hit the EU with 50pc tariffs . Brent crude fell below $64 per barrel, capping off a week of declines that has seen it fall by around 3pc .  The Vix index, Wall Street's fear gauge, spiked to its highest level in two week . Trump also warned he would make Apple pay tariffs if it does not start making iPhones in the US . The tech giant’s shares sank by around 4pc ahead of the opening bell . The Dow Jones Industrial Average was down 1.3pc, the S&P 500 dropped 1.5pc and the Nasdaq 100 was lower .  Donald Trump’s imposition of a 50pc tariff will do little to convince Brussels that it should be kinder to the US on trade . A handful of EU capitals had already blocked the possibility of offering to unilaterally reduce tariffs on US goods .  The US 30-year bond yield had hit its highest level in 18-months over concerns that the $36 trillion American debt pile was becoming unsustainable . Investors had been looking nervously at bond markets this week as longer-term debt costs ticked higher in the run-up to the passing of the tax-cutting “big beautiful bill” by the House of Representatives .  Donald Trump has also threatened to hit Apple’s iPhones with fresh tariffs . The Republican said he would add import duties of 25pc to any iPhones built overseas . The move could increase the price of the smartphones by hundreds of dollars .  White House officials have repeatedly raised the prospect of a 'Made in America' iPhone . Currently the majority of its phones are built in China by its Taiwanese supplier, Foxconn . But the long-running trade disputes between the US and Beijing have prompted it to shift production elsewhere .  The pan-European Stoxx 600 index has now dropped by more than 1pc in the wake of Donald Trump’s Truth Social post . Traders had favoured just two reductions before the post on Truth Social . ECB would likely need to cut interest rates to support growth in US economy, which would be hampered by higher tariffs from the US .

President Donald Trump demanded Apple and other smartphone makers make their phones in the United States or face a 25% tariff . Trump last week during his Middle East trip said he was displeased with Apple’s CEO, Tim Cook, over the plans to manufactureiPhones set to be sold in the US at newly built plants in India .  Apple had been working to diversify its iPhone production capabilities in India . Unlike Apple, Samsung doesn't rely on China for smartphone production . The South Korea-based tech giant closed its last phone factory in China in 2019 .  Apple CEO Tim Cook met with Trump at the White House on Tuesday, an administration official says . Roughly 90% of Apple’s iPhone production and assembly is based in China . Trump met with Cook in Riyadh at the beginning of his Middle East trip .  Some of Apple’s chips are already made in the United States, thanks to its partnership with TSMC, which recently opened a chipmaking plant in Arizona . Apple has long contended that it cannot manufacture iPhones in America .  Steve Jobs, Apple’s late CEO, famously brought up the issue during an October 2010 meeting with former President Barack Obama . Jobs called America’�s lackluster education system an obstacle for Apple, which needed 30,000 industrial engineers to support its on-site factory workers . In a 2012 interview with tech journalists Kara Swisher and Walt Mossberg, Apple CEO Tim Cook said he agreed with Jobs’ assessment .  iPhones could cost more than three times their current price of around $1,000, Ives says . He estimates moving all of Apple’s iPhone production to the United States would take five to 10 years . Even then, it would cost Apple about $30 billion and three years to move just 10% of its supply chain to the US .  Apple is considering raising prices when it releases its new lineup of iPhones in the fall . The company will likely avoid directly attributing the increases to tariffs . Apple announced a $500 billion investment to expand its US facilities earlier this year .  Apple plans to invest in corporate facilities and production of Apple TV+ shows in 20 states . It will also expand data center capacity in several states .

Apple CEO Tim Cook can't seem to catch a break . Trump expressed frustration about the tech giant producing the iPhone in other parts of Asia . Apple didn't respond to a request for comment about the remarks .  Trump has pushed for companies to build and manufacture products in the United States . Shifting production to the U.S. would take years and result in price hikes for consumers . The tariffs are expected to start in June .  In the June quarter, Apple expects to source the majority of iPhones sold in the United States from India . Apple makes most of its iPhones in China, but has expanded production in India, Vietnam and other countries . Foxconn, a Taiwanese electronics contract manufacturer that assembles Apple's products, is planning to build a $1.5-billion plant in India .  Tariffs would make it more expensive to repair an iPhone because the smartphone includes parts that come from other countries including China, Taiwan, South Korea and Japan . Apple isn't alone in navigating the potential impact of tariffs . Other U.S. companies including Walmart have said they would raise prices as they face political pressure .  Trump has criticized companies such as Mattel and Amazon for raising prices . Cook has previously said that Apple depends on China for the skill of its workforce . Trump has also criticized companies like Mattel, which is considering raising prices, and Amazon .  Trump's on-again, off-again tariffs have meant that businesses such as Apple are also facing economic uncertainty . Last week, the U.S. struck a deal with Chinese officials to roll back most tariffs for 90 days . Apple has been monitoring the potential impact of tariffs .

Apple CEO Tim Cook has been friendlier with President Trump than most big-company executives . Trump has threatened a 25% tariff on iPhones unless Apple makes them in the United States . Apple is unusual among tech giants in that its main offering is actually a physical product rather than software packaged as a service . Even with a 25% tariff, it makes no sense to move iPhone production to the United States . Trump is less hostile toward India and Vietnam, so it's reasonable to think he'll impose fewer barriers on imports from those countries . But there's no place to hide once Trump starts imposing tariffs on product-by-product basis .  If all smartphones came with a 25% tariff, Apple might be less disadvantaged . Cook might still be able to work some kind of deal with Trump that involves other types of domestic spending that would satisfy Trump .  If Trump does impose tariffs on iPhones, it would be under emergency authority . President Donald Trump threatens to slap a 25% tariff on the popular device . Apple for decades has been building most of its devices in China, where it has invested tens of billions of dollars . Apple CEO Tim Cook said earlier this month that most iPhones sold in the U.S. during the March-June period would come from India .  Most analysts believe if Apple somehow could suddenly start making iPhones in the U.S., prices for the devices would soar to at least $2,000 and possibly might rise as high as $3,500 . The disincentives for Apple shifting its production domestically include a complex supply chain that Cook began to engineer during the 1990s while he was working for his predecessor, Steve Jobs .  Wedbush Securities analyst Dan Ives says moving iPhone production in the U.S. is a 'nonstarter' He estimates the price of an iPhone made in China or India would soar to more than $3,000 if production shifted to the U., he says . Ives predicts Cook will engage in a “game of negotiations” with Trump that would spare the iPhone from tariffs .  Cook said tariffs had a “limited impact” on the company in the March quarter because it was able to optimize its supply chain . Cook warned that it is “very difficult” to predict beyond June “because I’m not sure what will happen with tariffs”  Apple has had wiggle room to hold the line on iPhone pricing because of its service revenue . The company continues to reap huge profit margins from the revenue generated by subscriptions and other services tied to its product . A federal judge recently issued an order barring Apple from collecting commissions on transactions within iPhone apps .  U.S. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick predicted tariffs would force a shift in manufacturing . Apple CEO Cook expressed doubt about whether the U.K. labor pool had enough workers with the skills required to do the work .  “ fill multiple football fields” fill multiple fields,” says former NFL star . “I’m sure it’s not just a football field filled with football fields. fill multiple stadiums,’ says former player .

President Trump threatened Apple with 25% tariffs on overseas-made iPhones . The president has made similar threats against companies since his first term in office . He has a history of not following through on these threats .  Apple's stock fell more than 2% on Friday morning following Trump's warning . In recent weeks, Trump has also called out at least four other companies by name over the possibility of raising prices due to tariffs .  Trump announced he was"recommending" a 50% tariff on the European Union in a separate post Friday morning . Also Friday morning, Trump announced that he was recommending a similar tariff on Apple, citing an “Herculean-like supply chain logistics needed”  The number of companies Trump has threatened over the years grows much longer when threats over non-tariff issues are included . Trump’s new move against Apple appears to be in reaction to news earlier this week that Foxconnwill investan additional $1.5 billion in factories in India .  "Liberation Day" is drawing on a 1977 law called the International Emergency Economic Powers Act . Other powers let him target sectors like steel or semiconductors, but they can require investigations .

US President Donald Trump says he expects Apple to make iPhones in the US . The president tweeted Friday that he expects a 25% tariff to be paid by Apple . US-made iPhones will likely cost more than three times their current price of around $1,000, analyst says .  The making and assembly of smartphone parts shifted to Asia decades ago, as American companies focused on software development and product design . That move has helped make Apple one of the world’s most valuable companies and cement itself as a dominant smartphone maker .  About 90% of Apple’s iPhone production takes place in China . The chips that power iPhones are mainly manufactured in Taiwan, while screen panels are supplied by South Korean companies . Apple still faces a 20% tariff on Chinese goods for the country's role in the fentanyl trade .  Apple has been seeking to diversify its production bases from China to India and Brazil . Analyst: It would be difficult for Apple not to raise iPhone prices if it faces tariffs of 30% or higher .

Apple stock fell about 2.5% in mid-morning trading on Friday . President Donald Trump threatened new tariffs on iPhones made in India . Apple stock is down almost 20% so far this year .  Last year, the company assembled $22 billion worth of iPhones in India and exported $17.5 billion . The vast majority of iPhones are still made in China, but Apple has been seeking to diversify .

ChatGPT, OpenAI’s text-generating AI chatbot, has taken the world by storm since its launch in November 2022 . The company has been hit with lawsuits from Alden Global Capital-owned newspapersalleging copyright infringement .  ChatGPT has been updating its product updates and releases throughout the year . The company plans to purchase Jony Ive's devices startup io for $6.4 billion . OpenAI says codex-1 generates more precise and cleaner code than o3 .  ChatGPT deep research feature lets developers connect with GitHub to ask questions about codebases and engineering documents . The connector will soon be available for chatGPT Plus, Pro, and Team users, with support for Enterprise and Education coming .  OpenAI is unveiling a program called OpenAI for Countries . The program will help organizations in Asia meet their local data sovereignty requirements when using OpenAI's products . The AI startup will work with governments to assist with increasing data center capacity .  The default AI model powering ChatGPT, GPT-4o, has been rolled back . The company is working on "additional fixes" to the model's personality . Users on social media criticized the new model for being too validating and agreeable .  OpenAI has added a few features to its ChatGPT search tool to give users an improved online shopping experience . The chatbot provides recommendations, images, and reviews of products in various categories such as fashion, beauty, home goods, and electronics .  OpenAI released a new AI model called GPT-4.1 in mid-April . Independent tests indicate that the model is less reliable than previous OpenAI releases . Questions have been raised regarding OpenAI's transparency and procedures for testing models .  OpenAI has released two new reasoning models, o3 and o4 mini, for biological and chemical threats . The company claims o3 is the most advanced reasoning model it has developed, while o4-mini is said to provide a balance of price, speed and performance .  OpenAI will discontinue its largest AI model, GPT-4.5, from its API . The move shows how commercial AI developers face more pressure to rapidly implement models . OpenAI is in the early stages of developing its own social media platform to compete with Elon Musk's X and Mark Zuckerberg's Instagram and Threads .  GPT-4.1 will rival AI models such as Google's Gemini 2.5 Pro, Anthropic's Claude 3.7 Sonnet, and DeepSeek's upgraded V3.3 . OpenAI may launch several new AI models soon, according to a report .  AI researcher Tibor Blahospotted a new "ImageGen" watermark feature in the new beta of ChatGPT's Android app . OpenAI is working on a watermarking feature for images generated using GPT-4o . The feature is rolling out to users in the U.K., EU, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Norway, Switzerland .  The Arc Prize Foundation updated the estimated computing costs for OpenAI's o3 "reasoning" model . The organization originally estimated that the best-performing configuration of o3 would cost approximately $3,000 to address a single problem . The Foundation now thinks the cost could be around $30,000 per task .  OpeanAI plans to release its "first" open language modelsinceGPT-2"in the coming months . The company plans to host developer events to gather feedback and showcase prototypes of the model .  MCP is an open-source standard that lets developers create bidirectional links between data sources and AI applications like chatbots . OpenAI expects revenue to triple to $12.7 billion in 2025, fueled by the performance of its paid AI software .  ChatGPT can now usethe GPT-4omodel to generate and edit images and photos directly . The feature went live earlier this week for subscribers of the company’s Pro plan, priced at $200 a month . The release of the image generation feature to free users would be delayed due to higher demand than the company expected .  OpenAI has updated its AI voice assistant with improved chat capabilities . The update enables real-time conversations, and the AI assistant is said to be more personable and interrupts users less often . Users on ChatGPT's free tier can now access the new version of Advanced Voice Mode .  Reliance has proposed selling OpenAI’s models to businesses in India through an application programming interface (API) Meta plans to bolster its presence in India by constructing a large 3GW data center in Jamnagar, Gujarat .  OpenAI has added new transcription and voice-generating AI models to its API . The company claims they are improved versions of what was already there and that they hallucinate less .  OpenAI has not extensively explored the use of AI for writing fiction . The company has mostly concentrated on challenges in rigid areas such as math and programming . OpenAI CEO Sam Altman said the company hastrained a “new model” that’s “really good” at creative writing .  OpenAI’s new Responses API enables enterprises to develop customized AI agents that can perform web searches, scan through company files, and navigate websites . The most expensive rumored agents are said to be aimed at supporting “PhD-level research,” are expected to cost $20,000 per month .  The latest version of the MacOS ChatGPT app allows users to edit code directly in supported developer tools, including Xcode, VS Code, and JetBrains . It's unclear when these agentic tools might launch or which customers will be eligible to buy them .  OpenAI has effectively canceled the release of o3 in favor of what CEO Sam Altman is calling a “simplified” product offering . ChatGPT usage spiked from April to May 2024, shortly after that model’s launch . Altman said in the coming months, OpenAI will release a model called GPT-5 that “integrates a lot of [OpenAI's] technology,” including o3 .  ChatGPT users will see an updated “chain of thought” that shows more of the model’s “reasoning” steps and how it arrived at answers to questions . OpenAI announced a new AI “agent” called deep research designed to help people conduct in-depth, complex research .  OpenAI launched a new AI “reasoning” model, o3-mini, the newest in the company’s o family of models . The company says it collects user posts from Reddit and tests its AI models to measure their persuasive abilities .  OpenAI has launched ChatGPT Gov to provide U.S. government agencies an additional way to access the tech . Pew Research Center polled young people in a new survey . Pew: Twenty-six percent of teens say they've used chatGPT for homework or other assignments .  OpenAI says it might store chats and screenshots from customers who use Operator, the company's AI “agent” tool, for up to 90 days . Operator promises to automate tasks such as booking travel accommodations, making restaurant reservations, and shopping online .  OpenAI has begun testing a beta feature that lets new ChatGPT users sign up with only a phone number . The feature is currently in beta in the U.S. and India . Users who create an account using their number can’t upgrade to one of the paid plans without an email .  ChatGPT is a general-purpose chatbot that uses artificial intelligence to generate text after a user enters a prompt . The chatbot uses GPT-4, a large language model that uses deep learning to produce human-like text .  ChatGPT is AI-powered and utilizes LLM technology to generate text after a prompt . A chatbot can be any software/system that holds dialogue with you/a person but doesn't necessarily have to be AI . Microsoft announced at its 2023 Build conference that it is integrating its chatbot-based Bing experience into Windows 11 .  ChatGPTwill is not documented anywhere that ChatGPT has a character limit . However, users have noted that there are some character limitations after around 500 words . The app can write Python code but it can’t necessarily program an entire app’s worth of code .  OpenAI allows users to save chats in the ChatGPT interface, stored in the sidebar of the screen . There are no built-in sharing features yet . OpenAI has said individuals in “certain jurisdictions” can object to the processing of their personal information by its AI models .  An Australian mayor has publicly announced he may sue OpenAI for defamation due to false claims that he had served time in prison for bribery . This would be the first defamation lawsuit against the text-generating service .  New York City Public Schools have banned ChatGPT from their networks and devices . School systems and colleges claim the AI impedes the learning process by promoting plagiarism and misinformation . Several marketplaces host and provide chatGPT prompts .  Text-generating AI models like ChatGPT have a tendency to regurgitate content from their training data . Yes. touch on chatGPT .

Bond investors are demanding more compensation to hold long-dated US debt . The US 10-year term premium has climbed to near 1%, a level last seen in 2014 . It's a measure of how jittery investors are about plans to raise the scale of future borrowing . Moody's Ratings stripped the nation of its last top-tier credit score .  US long-term borrowing costs surged this week, with the 30-year yield climbing to 5.15% . The real rate for the same tenor — which is adjusted for inflation — closed at the most elevated level since 2008 . The moves eased on Friday as the selloff attracted buyers and President Donald Trump threatened a sweeping tariffs on the European Union and Apple .  Bank of America’s Michael Hartnett said investors should take the opportunity to add long-dated Treasuries as the US government is likely to heed warnings from bond vigilantes to bring its debt under control . Term premium in 10-year notes was far higher than it is now . In the first decade of this century, it averaged a level of more than 150 basis points .  Similar debt in the UK, Germany and Australia has also faced selling pressure . It’s a reminder that governments can’t keep borrowing at the pace they did when interest rates were close to zero .  Japanese bond markets were particularly hit by the latest selloff . The Bank of Japan is scaling back its bond purchases as inflation accelerates . Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba said this week the nation’s financial conditions are worse than Greece's .  Japan may consider asking government-owned entities to support the nation’s bond market if the selloff in longer-dated debt doesn’t abate . Deutsche Bank AG warns the rising Japanese debt could force sales of US Treasuries in order to pay for domestic bonds .  Albert Edwards, a global strategist at Societe Generale SA, said that while US bond and stock markets have previously benefited from money flowing from Japan, this may now be reversing . He said the surging long end of the JGB market is the No. 1 most important thing for investors at the moment .

For now, this is just talk . But with the 2024 race heating up and reshoring back in the spotlight, Apple investors may want to start scenario planning .

CoreWeave Inc. shares have been on a tear as investors snap up the stock despite concerns about elevated debt levels and cash burn . The shares have more than doubled in price in May after CoreWeaves reported a deal with OpenAI worth as much as $4 billion to rent out computing power to process artificial intelligence demands . Microsoft Corp. have recently pledged to keep spending heavily on AI computing .  CoreWeave shares are up more than 160% since the firm went public at $40 a share in March . The company’s believers have been winning out, helped by the relatively limited number of shares available to trade . The stock fell 6.7% on Thursday after rising 19% the day before .  CoreWeave has specialized in marshaling high-powered chips from Nvidia Corp. Nvidia held 7% of its shares as of March 31 . Short sellers are betting against the company's rising share price . This could lead to a spiral of buying known as a short squeeze that would push stock even higher .  In the first quarter, CoreWeave’s loss per share widened to $1.49 a share, up from 62 cents a year ago . The company is targeting $20 billion to $23 billion in capital spending this year, which will be funded by raising debt .  Davidson analyst Gil Luria compared CoreWeave to troubled co-working company WeWork . Luria said it is not worth scaling the business due to the small returns it has achieved relative to its borrowing costs . The company did not immediately respond to a request for comment . American President Donald Trump has threatened to put a 25% tariff on Apple products unless iPhones are manufactured in the US . Mr Trump also threatened a 50% tax on all imports from the European Union . The threat delivered over social media could increase the price of iPhones .  Mr Trump said he wants to charge higher import taxes on goods from the EU, a long-standing US ally, than from China . Mr Trump was upset by the lack of progress in trade talks with the EU . The US leader also brought it up last week during his Middle East trip .

U.S. President Donald Trump cranked up his trade threats on Friday, targeting both smartphone giant Apple and imports from the European Union . Trump threatened to impose a 25% tariff on Apple for any iPhones sold, but not manufactured, in the United States . He also said he would recommend a 50% . tariff on the EU to begin on June 1 . Stock indexes in the U .S. and across Europe fell, although they pared earlier sharper losses .  Trump's renewed trade threats against Apple and the EU disrupt the period of relative calm in global trade tensions, raising risks for tech and multinational firms ahead of low-liquidity holiday weekend in the United States . The timing heightens the potential for outsized market reactions as investors reassess geopolitical risks and brace for possible European retaliatory measures .  "Markets go through a cycle with tariffs - freak out and sell when they are announced, but that’s the pattern" "We need to remember who drives the market – the marginal buyer or seller"  Investors need to make sure they are not stuck in the middle, with a three- to six-month time horizon . That's too long a time period to profit from short-term trading opportunities created by volatility .  The renewed tariff war with Europe is going to affect the U.S. as well as Europe . It's going to be causing investors to move into money market funds, just to hide out .  Every company could be subject to higher tariffs and that it would be very difficult to select individual companies that could end up outperforming . “I would conclude that no company is safe after Trump has singled out Apple. many ways there’s no place to hide.”  Europe has the second largest trade surplus with the U.S. after China . Such a level of tariff would be relevant for pharmaceuticals, autos . Support industries like logistics continue to look interesting as the state of play develops .  On the threat of tariffs on Apple, it may create an additional political challenge to the Trump administration once they are enacted . As consumers see prices going up, they'll be upset and concerned about it . Sales of iPhones in the U.S. are very high, across the income distribution .  The EU is a big economic entity with influence in trade negotiations and probably thinks it can stand its ground with America and will be prepared to tolerate some pain, as opposed to giving into requests from Trump that EU officials think are unreasonable . Trump is highly volatile and I would not bet on this coming through."  Even the fact that he’s used the phrase “I recommend” suggests this is part of the late stage negotiation tactics . But if they’re even close to being implemented, then Europe's retaliation would be very significant so quite problematic."  Treasury yields are lower ahead of the open this morning in response to a safe-haven bid over the past few minutes on additional tariff threats from President Trump . U.S. equity index futures spent most of the night narrowly mixed, but have declined on the latest development .  We believe the concept of Apple producing iPhones in the US is a fairy tale that is not feasible . Take 5-10 years to shift production to the U.S.

The threats, delivered over social media, reflect Trump's ability to disrupt the global economy . Trump was upset by the lack of progress in trade talks with the EU, which has proposed mutually cutting tariffs to zero .  The EU’s top trade official, Maros Sefcovic, posted on social media site X that he spoke Friday with U.S. trade officials . “The EU-US trade is unmatched & must be guided by mutual respect, not threats. We stand ready to defend our interests.”  Apple joins Amazon, Walmart and other major U.S. companies in the White House's crosshairs . Trump later clarified his post to say that all smartphones made abroad would be taxed .  Apple CEO Tim Cook said earlier this month that most iPhones sold in the U.S. during the current fiscal quarter would come from India . After Trump rolled out tariffs in April, bank analysts estimated that a $1,200 iPhone would if made in America jump in price . Stocks sold off after Trump's postings, with the S&P 500 index down roughly 0.67%.  Bessent said the EU has a “collective action problem” because its 27 member states are represented by “this one group in Brussels,” such that the “underlying countries don’t even know what the EU is negotiating on their behalf” The goal was to have Apple bring more of its chip supply chain into the U.S.  German Foreign Minister Johann Wadephul said the EU has his country’s full support in working to “preserve our access to the American market” Trump aides have said the goal of his tariffs was to isolate China and strike new agreements with allies .  Trump has run hot and cold on his relationship with Apple, a sign that currying favor with him might not necessarily shield a trade deal . Mary Lovely, a senior fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics, said the 50% tariffs on Europe are most likely a “negotiating ploy” by Trump .  Trump could remove exemption on electronics imported from China to help Apple . He also threatened separate 25% import taxes on computer chips and could have the tariffs schedule rewritten in ways that could expose Apple products .  Analysts have been skeptical that Apple could quickly shift device manufacturing to the U.S. Apple has spent decades embedding complex supply chains in China to feed the factories . But it also has the challenge of grappling with “the unpredictable nature of the current . administration,” analyst says . Googledemonstratedsmart glasses powered by its Android XR platform and announced that eyewear makers Warby Parker and Gentle Monster would be selling products based on it . The next day, OpenAI unveiled its$6.5 billion acquisition of Jony Ive’s startup IO, which will put the Apple design legend at the center of the ChatGPT maker's quest to build devices around its AI .  Android XR scratches the same itch Google has had since it unveiled its ill-fated Google Glassa dozen years ago . Apple hopes to release its own Siri-enhanced smart glasses next year .  Google's Android XR prototype resembles a slightly chunky pair of conventional glasses . It uses a conversational voice interface and a transparent mini-display that floats on your view of your surroundings . Google says shipping products will have “all-day” battery life, a claim that Glass could never make .  The announcement of the merger of OpenAI and IO’s merger was as polished as a Jony Ive-designed product . Altman and Ive smothered each other in praise and talked about reinventing computing . Absent any specifics, Altman's assessment of one of Ive's prototypes sounded like runaway enthusiasm at best and Barnumesque puffery at worst .  Jin cites Altman predicting that it will sell 100 million units faster than any product before it . In 2007, by contrast, Apple forecast selling a more modest 10 million iPhones in the phone’s first full year on the market .  You can't accuse Apple of hyping any smart glasses it might release in 2026 . Until you have a product in the market, it’s better to tamp down expectations than stoke them . Even companies that aren’t presently trying to earn back their AI cred should take note .  Plugged In is Fast Company’s weekly tech newsletter from me, global technology editor Harry McCracken . If anything released next year gets there, it might bethelandmark AI gizmo we haven’t yet seen .  A new app, Verb.AI, wants to pay the generation that’s most laissez-faire on digital privacy for their scrolling time . As AI evolves, businesses should use the technology to complement, not replace, human workers .  Without spending a dime, you can make your money without having to spend it . You can do so much more than a million dollars without spending a dollar . The company is now focusing on the next generation of tech entrepreneurs .

The twin threats roiled global markets after weeks of de-escalation had provided some reprieve in the tariff battle . Major U.S. stock indexes and European shares fell and the dollar weakened, while the price of gold rose .  The president's attack on Apple is his latest attempt to pressure a specific company to move production to the United States . The U.S. does not mass-produce smartphones, and moving production would likely increase the cost of iPhones by hundreds of dollars . Trump said he expects the new phone levy to be in place by the end of June .  EU trade chief Maros Sefcovic says EU-U.S. trade "must be guided by mutual respect, not threats" Dutch Prime Minister Dick Schoof backs the EU's strategy in trade talks . The White House paused most of the punishing tariffs Trump announced in early April .  A 50% levy on EU imports could raise consumer prices on everything from German cars to Italian olive oil . The EU's total exports to the United States last year totaled about 500 billion euros . Pharmaceuticals, cars and auto parts, chemicals and aircraft were among the largest exports . The White House has been in trade negotiations with numerous countries but progress has been unsteady .  Japan's top trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa said the two sides discussed expanding trade, non-tariff barriers and economic security issues . He described their talks as franker and more in-depth than before . U.S. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent would not comment on other potential trade deals .  Apple declined to comment on Trump's threat to reverse exclusions he granted on smartphones and other electronics imported largely from China . Apple is speeding up plans to make most iPhones sold in the United States at factories in India by the end of 2026 to navigate potentially higher tariffs in China .  "Hard to imagine that Apple can be fully compliant with this request from the president in the next 3-5 years," analyst Gil Luria said .

Emory Healthcare has announced implementation of Apple products at its Emory Hillandale Hospital in Lithonia, Georgia, US . Each patient room features an iMac on a swing arm, aiding clinicians with bedside charting and documentation . iPhones and Apple Watches keep them connected with the Epic electronic health record system .  iPad kiosks using the Epic Welcome app for quick and secure check-ins . Bedside iPads in every room enable patients to engage with their care plans, review medical records and order meals . Essential safety information is displayed on the wall-mounted iPads outside patient rooms .  Information on this site has been included in good faith for general informational purposes only . We give no representation, warranty or guarantee as to its accuracy or completeness .

US president threatened Apple (AAPL) with a25% tariff unless it manufactures its iPhones in the US . Apple shares were down 2% on the back of the news . Trump also recommended a 50% tariff on goods from the European Union from the start of next month .  Wall Street’s ‘fear gauge’, the VIX rose as much as 13.5% on Friday on the back of the announcements . This came asOfgem lowered its energy price capfor UK households and government data showed an unexpected jump in retail sales . London's benchmark index tumbled 0.3% as trade war fears swept the City again .  Germany's DAX (^GDAXI) dived 1.6% and the CAC (^FCHI) in Paris headed 1.8% into the red . Dow Jones Industrial Average (^DJI)sank 1%, or over 400 points, down 1% on Wall Street . Pound hit $1.35 for the first time since February 2022; dollar weakens against basket of currencies .  US markets will be closed on Monday for Memorial Day holiday . UK markets will also be closed for the late May bank holiday . Major focus will be on Nvidia (NVDA), which is due to release first quarter earnings on Wednesday . Salesforce (CRM) and Dell (DELL) also set to report on Thursday . Costco (COST) will be looking at retail sector results to gauge US consumer sentiment .  Detelina Subeva has been banned from the UK financial services industry . She is the third ex-Credit Suisse employee to be banned for lacking integrity . The Financial Conduct Authority fined Credit Suisse over £145m in October 2021 . French trade minister Laurent Saint-Martin said Donald Trump’s threat of new tariffs against the EU are not helping trade negotiations .  The FCA secured Credit Suisse’s agreement to write off $200m of debt owed by the Republic of Mozambique . The loans were tainted by corruption . Subeva's co-conspirators, Andrew Pearse and Surjan Singh, were banned earlier in February 2025 .  Games Workshop to hand out £20m to staff after growing sales and profits over past year . Company expects revenues for latest financial year to be at least £560m, up from £495m the year before .  GfK’s long-running consumer confidence index increased by three points to -20 in May . Pre-tax profits for the year are estimated to be at least £255m, up from £203m last year .  President Donald Trump has said he is "recommending" 50% tariffs on imported goods from the EU . This is up from the blanket 10% tariff goods being brought into America, as "discussions with them are going nowhere" The pound has hit $1.35 against the US dollar for the first time since February 2022 .  Oil prices fell on Friday morning, putting them on track for a weekly loss . The fall in oil prices came after Bloomberg reported that OPEC+ were discussing making a third consecutive increase in output . US-Iran nuclear deal talks are reportedly set to resume on Friday .  OPEC is said to be mulling over another 411,000 barrel per day increase in output for July . The prospect of an increase in supply into the oil market comes amid lingering concerns about demand .  Gerry Cardinale, founder of the US private equity firm, has signed an agreement in principle to acquire control of the newspaper for £500m . RedBird IMI, an investment vehicle majority backed by the United Arab Emirates, was blocked by the government last year following a parliamentary outcry over press freedom .  International Paper said it plans to close five packaging sites across the UK, relocate a sixth and implement a “small headcount reduction” at two additional locations . The restructuring could affect approximately 300 roles and is expected to be completed by the end of the year . The move marks one of the first major changes under International Paper’s ownership of DS Smith .  FTSE 350 stocks are trading on steep discounts, despite outperforming the UK market over five years . The list of companies ranges from household names to industrial firms . A lower p/e ratio can indicate a company is undervalued .  FTSE 100 (^FTSE) hit a fresh all-time high in March and is currently trading near record levels . US markets, meanwhile, have experienced more volatility as US president Donald Trump pushed ahead with his tariff agenda . Choppy trading has left the S&P 500 (^GSPC) in the red year-to-date .  Manufacturing output and exports grew faster in March than initially forecast . Companies scrambled to beat Trump’s announcement of new tariffs in April . It was the fastest quarterly growth since the third quarter of 2022 .  April’s retail sales growth surpassed expectations, with analysts having predicted a 0.4% increase . ONS said the latest increase means growth over the past three months has been the ‘largest in nearly four years’ Food stores reported a 3.9% rise in sales volumes – the strongest performance since January .  Nikkei (^N225) rose 0.5% on the day in Japan, while the Hang Seng (^HSI) was flat Hong Kong . The Japanese yen strengthened 0.42% against the US dollar this morning, although much of that has been driven by dollar weakness . In the bond market, the yield on benchmark 10-year US Treasury notes has recovered .  UK retail sales for April fell to 4.540% from 4.588% a day earlier . French consumer confidence for May and US new home sales data for April . Central bank speakers include the Fed’s Musalem, Schmid and Cook .

Chinese consumer electronics giant Xiaomi has launched a new electric SUV and debuted a self-designed smartphone chip . The YU7 SUV will offer a driving range of up to 835 kilometers (518 miles) on a single drive . The Xring O1 is a 3-nanometer mobile chip meant to rival those powering Apple and Qualcomm’s top-tier smartphones .  The top model will be able to accelerate from zero to 100 kilometers per hour (62 miles per hour) in just over three seconds . The standard models will come with advanced driving assistance software . Xiaomi’s automobile business has come under scrutiny in recent months after an SU7 sedan was involved in a fatal highway accident in March .  Xring O1 chip will debut in Xiaomi’s 15S Pro smartphone, which retails for $764 . Xiaomi only designs the chips and outsources the production of chips to the world's largest chipmaker . The achievement of designing three-nanometer chips puts Xiaomi ahead of another Chinese tech giant Huawei .  Xiaomi’s journey into developing its own chips has been years in the making . Xiaomi will commit at least 50 billion yuan ($7 billion) in investment over the coming decade to advance its chips .  China and the US are clashing over access to the most advanced semiconductors . Beijing has repeatedly lashed out at Washington for warning companies against using AI chips made by Huawei . It has even accused the Trump administration of “undermining” a consensus reached at recent trade talks .
Appleis offering additional trade-in discounts for new iPhones in China until June 18 . Apple is offering additional discounts for iPhone customers until the end of June .

Emory Hillandale Hospital in Georgia has become the first U.S. hospital to fully operate on Apple devices . The hospital will use iPads, iPhones, Apple Watches, iMacs, and Mac minis . Emory executives chose AAPL for its user-friendly design, robust cybersecurity, minimal IT support needs .  If successful, Emory plans to expand AAPL device use across its 10 hospitals . Dr. Sumbul Desai, vice president of health at Apple Inc. (NASDAQ:AAPL), said the company is “thrilled” to support Emory in delivering exceptional care .

Goldman Sachs keeps a Buy rating and $253 price target on Apple (AAPL) ahead of the company’s WWDC 2025 Keynote on June 9th . The firm expects the company to demonstrate continued progress toward incorporating AI into its operating systems .  OpenAI to buy Jony Ive’s hardware start-up io Products for $6.5B . Ive to take expansive role at OpenAI after startup acquired, WSJ reports .
